answers.answer: Interesting copyman.  I have to ponder what the dosage of Metformin would be for those who are not insulin resistant or have type 2 diabetes.  My husband takes etformin for type 2 diabetes.  It controls his glucose levels well and of course without it his reading are very high.  Granted he takes (4) 500 mg per day.  Wondering if even low doses of Metformin would make someone without IR or diabetes hypoglycemic and if not would low dose Metformin be effective is halting virus replication.Trinity

That sounds potentially very exciting.  Thank you for posting it.  It is on the $4.00 list at Walmart too.  Joe took it during TX but stopped afterward and it has been on my mind that he probably should still be taking it.  I am glad for anything at all that helps  no matter what category it falls in.Joe often tells me that he probably will die much sooner if I don't rub his feet . :>)Thanks again,Ev

Hi Trin,I believe metformin acts as an insulin sensitizer, rather than a drug that promotes insulin production.  It helps our body’s cells use insulin more efficiently; I don’t think it’s likely to promote hyperglycemia when taken without other antidiabetes meds. I have occasional periods of hyperglycemia but I also use Glipizide and Avandia.If you decide to incorporate it, you might get GI upset/diarrhea for a week or two initially; we tend to acclimate to it quickly, but the first couple of weeks are interesting :o).For what it’s worth, I used 2g/day throughout my first Tx, but relapsed anyway; so don’t expect it to be a panacea.--Bill

On the other hand, didn't you take metformin duing you second tx along with insulin and achive SVR?  If so, it proves that metformin and insulin, without a doubt,  have a positive effect in the eradication of HCV.  (I'm sure that 96 weeks of treatment with 2000 mg/day of riba was just incidental to the outcome)
Aha, so maybe it was the *insulin* the second time around :o). Heck, I don’t know; I used 1800 mg/day riba for most of that first treatment too; I guess this is why they run studies….Bill

I guess that I need to give a metformin testimonial too.  After achieving SVR I've been on 2000 mg of metformin per day.  I am still SVR.  Therefore, metformin also provides a protective shield (almost like a vaccine) against further infection.  The stuff is great, the stuff is cheap - if only they could miniaturize those horse pills somewhat.

I find it somewhat mindboggling, but so very interesting, the multitude of trials ongoing for HCV treatment - pharmaceuticals, off label meds and supplements. It's good to know research continues to explore the possibilties.I wonder if some where down the line, we may use supps or an off label med to suppress viral load prior to tx, then zap it with a potent pharmaceutical, but for a shorter length of time, then resume supps and or/off labels for further fibrosis reversal. From what I read also, the lean towards individualized tx is encouraging. Perhaps it'll come down to finding the right "blend" for each patient.
wow, this is surely worth watching. with the epidemic of obesity and type 2 diabetes peaking at the same time old heppers are coming out, there might be some good news here.

And, it may be worthwhile to shift some usually held public beliefs while your at it.  I have never had an overweight day in my like and I'm thinking that Bill is also of the long and lanky profile too
Avandia is a dodgy one sometimes due to heart issue , its been withdrawn across Europe ASAIK , might be worth checking,

Jusjames—good catch. I use Actos, but for some reason my fingers typed Avandia. Our FDA went through the same review on Avandia recently, and reluctantly left it on the shelf; however, it is used only when patients are found refractory to other, similar drugs, I believe.FlGuy, although I was down to 185 pounds at one point during treatment, I’m currently the lankiest 6’ 0” 250 pounder you’ve ever seen :o). I’ve always led an active lifestyle, so I don’t fit the sedentary profile of typical DM II patients. I imagine perhaps HCV hastened this along; although both my mother and father developed diabetes later in life as well.--Bill

question: It seems this forum is becoming an alternative / supplement forum so I hope it is ok to post this. Here is an interesting article about a prescription drug, the diabetic drug Metaformin. An old drug that has been around a long time. And is very inexpensive. They are finding it has many uses including anti-cancer properties. I think it is great when an existing  drug is found to work for other diseases. Especially drugs that patents have run out and are now inexpensive. Also Metaformin has shown promise against many cancers.  You will hear more about off label Metaformin use in the near future.Research led by the University of Leeds has found drugs such as anti-diabetic drug Metformin and AICAR, used to combat obesity, can prevent the hepatitis C virus from replicating in the body.Hepatitis C virus affects an estimated three per cent of the world's population and there are four million carriers of the virus in Europe alone. The virus affects the liver and recovery rates are low: only around 40 per cent of hepatitis C sufferers will fully recover, with others developing cirrhosis and in many cases, liver cancer."We're very excited about these findings," says Professor Mark Harris from the University's Faculty of Biological Sciences. "These drugs are already on the market, and whilst substantial clinical trials still need to take place before they can be used to treat hepatitis C infection, we think it could be an enormous step forward in the battle against the virus."The research was supported by the Wellcome Trust, the Medical Research Council and the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.Drugs such as Metformin and AICAR work by stimulating an enzyme called AMP kinase (AMPK) which regulates energy within our cells - the very enzyme that hepatitis C virus represses to enable it to replicate.AMPK's usual function is to conserve the energy balance in cells, which it does by temporarily shutting down the production of lipids (fats) and membranes when it senses an increase in energy requirements. Professor Harris and his team have now shown that the hepatitis C virus switches off AMPK so that the cell continues production of lipids and membranes, both of which are vital to its survival."You'd expect AMPK to be activated when a cell becomes infected by a virus, because it would sense the increase in energy required to enable the virus to replicate. In such cases, AMPK would shut down certain functions of the cell temporarily until the cell's energy is rebalanced," says Prof Harris. "We found that hepatitis C virus, because it needs lipids and membranes, causes the opposite to happen."Building on this finding, the research team were able to examine how cells would react when treated with common drugs that stimulate AMPK. They found that in infected cells, the drugs were able to halt virus replication, enabling cells to clear the infection.A patent has been filed on the discovery and the team will shortly embark on a small-scale clinical trial with The University of Nottingham. This will provide a greater evidence base upon which future clinical trials can be based.More information: This research is published in a paper entitled Enhanced hepatitis C virus genome replication and lipid accumulation mediated by inhibition of AMP-activated protein kinase in the latest edition of Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS).
title: Metaformin and HCV
